Chapter 11- Aircraft Electrical Systems AC 65-15A

Electrical Load Determination
Electrical Load
Determination

Load Analysis
Load Analysis

It should be determined that the total electrical load can be safely controlled or managed within the rated limits of the affected components of the aircraft’s electrical system.
It should be determined that the
total electrical load can be safely
controlled or managed within the
rated limits of the affected
components of the aircraft’s
electrical system.

New or additional electrical devices should not be installed without an electrical load analysis
New or additional electrical devices
should not be installed without an
electrical load analysis

Circuit Breaker Devices Should be sized so that it will open before the current rating of the wire attached to it is exceeded, or before the cumulative rating of all loads connected to it are exceeded, whichever is lowest.
Circuit Breaker Devices
Should be sized so that it will open
before the current rating of the wire
attached to it is exceeded, or
before the cumulative rating of all
loads connected to it are
exceeded, whichever is lowest.

Circuit Breaker Protection
Circuit Breaker
Protection

“A circuit breaker must always open before any component downstream can overheat and generate smoke or fire.” “Circuit breakers are designed as circuit protection for the wire, not for protection of black boxes or components.” Use of a circuit breaker as a switch is not recommended.
“A circuit breaker must always
open before any component
downstream can overheat and
generate smoke or fire.”
“Circuit breakers are designed as
circuit protection for the wire, not
for protection of black boxes or
components.”
Use of a circuit breaker as a switch
is not recommended.

Wire Selection
Wire Selection

Wires must be sized so that they
Wires must be sized so that they

have sufficient mechanical strength do not exceed allowable voltage drop levels are protected by circuit protection devices meet circuit current carrying requirements
have sufficient mechanical strength
do not exceed allowable voltage
drop levels
are protected by circuit protection
devices
meet circuit current carrying
requirements

Wire Selection
Wire Selection

Wire Selection
Wire Selection

Mechanical strength of wire sizes less than #20
Mechanical strength of wire sizes
less than #20

Wire with less than 19 strands should not be used Additional support at terminations Should not be used when subject to excessive vibration, repeated bending, or frequent disconnection
Wire with less than 19 strands
should not be used
Additional support at terminations
Should not be used when subject
to excessive vibration, repeated
bending, or frequent disconnection

Wire Selection Factors for Determining Current Carrying Capacity
Wire Selection
Factors for Determining Current
Carrying Capacity

Effect of insulation heat aging Max operating temperature Single wire or wires in a harness Altitude
Effect of insulation heat aging
Max operating temperature
Single wire or wires in a harness
Altitude

Tables in Section 5 of AC 43.13-1b provide an acceptable method of calculating wire resistance and current carrying capacity of wires
Tables in Section 5 of AC 43.13-1b
provide an acceptable method of
calculating wire resistance and
current carrying capacity of wires

Wire Selection
Wire Selection

Conductor Stranding
Conductor Stranding

Minimizes fatigue breakage
Minimizes fatigue breakage

Platings
Platings

all aircraft wiring is plated because bare copper develops a surface oxide film which is a poor conductor
all aircraft wiring is plated because
bare copper develops a surface
oxide film which is a poor
conductor

Tin < 150 degrees C Silver < 200 degrees C Nickel ---> 260 degrees C
Tin < 150 degrees C
Silver < 200 degrees C
Nickel ---> 260 degrees C

Wire Substitution
Wire Substitution

In the repair and modification of existing aircraft, when a replacement wire is required, the maintenance manual for that aircraft should first be reviewed to determine if the original aircraft manufacturer (OAM) has approved any substitution. If not, then the OAM should be contacted for an acceptable replacement
In the repair and modification of
existing aircraft, when a
replacement wire is required, the
maintenance manual for that
aircraft should first be reviewed to
determine if the original aircraft
manufacturer (OAM) has approved
any substitution. If not, then the
OAM should be contacted for an
acceptable replacement

Wire Insulation Selection
Wire Insulation
Selection

Characteristics should be chosen based on environment
Characteristics should
be chosen based on
environment

Abrasion resistance Arc resistance corrosion resistance Cut-through strength Dielectric strength
Abrasion resistance
Arc resistance
corrosion resistance
Cut-through strength
Dielectric strength

Flame resistant Mechanical strength Smoke emission Fluid resistance heat distortion
Flame resistant
Mechanical
strength
Smoke emission
Fluid resistance
heat distortion

The Challenge:
The Challenge:

Select the insulation system best-
Select the insulation system best-

suited for each application
suited for each application

Fact:
Fact:

There is no “perfect” insulation system for aerospace wire & cable
There is no “perfect” insulation
system for aerospace wire & cable

The Designer’s Task:
The Designer’s Task:

Consider trade-offs to secure best balance of properties Consider influence of design, installation and maintenance
Consider trade-offs to secure best
balance of properties
Consider influence of design, installation
and maintenance

.....For Each Application!
.....For Each Application!

HOW TO CHOOSE
HOW TO CHOOSE

Seek The Best Balance of
Seek The Best Balance of

Properties: Electrical Mechanical Chemical Thermal
Properties:
Electrical
Mechanical
Chemical
Thermal

Plus
Plus

Nonflammability & low smoke
Nonflammability & low smoke

Construction
Construction

Insulation Selection
Insulation Selection

Select with care
Select with care

seek proper balance of properties for each application
seek proper balance of properties for each
application

Consider outside influences
Consider outside influences

design requirements installation conditions proper maintenance
design requirements
installation conditions
proper maintenance

Choose materials with inherent flame/smoke resistance
Choose materials with inherent flame/smoke
resistance

Conclusion on Insulation
Conclusion on
Insulation

Aircraft designer can choose among many polymeric materials Physical and chemical properties are equally important Safest system combines “Balance of Properties” with inherent flame/smoke resistance
Aircraft designer can choose
among many polymeric materials
Physical and chemical properties
are equally important
Safest system combines “Balance
of Properties” with inherent
flame/smoke resistance

Routing and Clamping
Routing and Clamping

Wires should be supported by suitable clamps, grommets, or other devices at intervals of not more that 24 inches
Wires should be supported by
suitable clamps, grommets, or
other devices at intervals of not
more that 24 inches

The supporting devices should be of a suitable size and type with wire/cables held securely in place without damage to the wire or wire 28 insulation
The supporting devices should be
of a suitable size and type with
wire/cables held securely in place
without damage to the wire or wire
28
insulation

Routing and Clamping
Routing and Clamping

Stand-offs should be used to maintain clearance between wires and structure. Employing tape or tubing is generally not acceptable as an alternative Exception: Where it is impossible to install off-angle clamps to maintain wiring separation in holes, bulkheads, floors, etc.
Stand-offs should be used to
maintain clearance between wires
and structure. Employing tape or
tubing is generally not acceptable
as an alternative
Exception: Where it is impossible
to install off-angle clamps to
maintain wiring separation in holes,
bulkheads, floors, etc.

Clamps
Clamps

Wire bundles should not be able to move axially
Wire bundles should not be able to
move axially

RF Cables-do not crush Clamps mounted with attachment hardware on top Tying should not be used as alternative to clamping
RF Cables-do not crush
Clamps mounted with attachment
hardware on top
Tying should not be used as
alternative to clamping

Routing
Routing

Eliminate potential for chafing against structure or other components Position wiring such that it is not likely to be used as handholds or support Route, if practicable, to minimize exposure to damage by maintenance crews or shifting cargo Route to avoid battery electrolytes or other corrosive fluids
Eliminate potential for chafing against
structure or other components
Position wiring such that it is not likely to
be used as handholds or support
Route, if practicable, to minimize
exposure to damage by maintenance
crews or shifting cargo
Route to avoid battery electrolytes or
other corrosive fluids

Routing
Routing

Protect wires in wheel wells and other exposed areas route wires above fluid lines, if practicable Use drip loops to control fluids or condensed moisture Enough slack to allow maintenance, and prevent mechanical strain.
Protect wires in wheel wells and other
exposed areas
route wires above fluid lines, if
practicable
Use drip loops to control fluids or
condensed moisture
Enough slack to allow maintenance, and
prevent mechanical strain.

Wire Bend Radii
Wire Bend Radii

Minimum Radius- 10 times the outside diameter of the largest wire or cable in the group Exceptions
Minimum Radius- 10 times the
outside diameter of the largest wire
or cable in the group
Exceptions

terminations/reversing direction in bundle - 3 times the diameter RF Cables- 6 times thermocouple wire- 20 times
terminations/reversing direction in
bundle - 3 times the diameter
RF Cables- 6 times
thermocouple wire- 20 times

Unused Wires
Unused Wires

Secured
Secured

tied into a bundle or secured to a permanent structure
tied into a bundle or secured to a
permanent structure

Individually cut with strands even with insulation. Pre-insulated closed end connector or 1 inch piece of insulating tubing folded and tied 34 back
Individually cut with strands even
with insulation.
Pre-insulated closed end
connector or 1 inch piece of
insulating tubing folded and tied
34
back

Wire Replacement
Wire Replacement

Should be replaced when:
Should be replaced when:

chafed/frayed or insulation is suspected of being penetrated outer insulation is brittle such that flexing causes cracking damaged by or known to have been exposed to electrolyte, oil, hydraulic fluid, etc. evidence of overheating
chafed/frayed or insulation is
suspected of being penetrated
outer insulation is brittle such that
flexing causes cracking
damaged by or known to have
been exposed to electrolyte, oil,
hydraulic fluid, etc.
evidence of overheating

Wire Replacement (cont.)
Wire Replacement
(cont.)

Wire should be replaced when
Wire should be replaced when

bears evidence of being crushed or kinked shield on shielded wire ir frayed and/or corroded shows evidence of beaks, cracks, dirt, or moisture in plastic sleaving sections of wire in which splices 36 occur at less than 10 ft intervals
bears evidence of being crushed or
kinked
shield on shielded wire ir frayed
and/or corroded
shows evidence of beaks, cracks,
dirt, or moisture in plastic sleaving
sections of wire in which splices
36
occur at less than 10 ft intervals

Wire Splicing
Wire Splicing

Kept to a minimum and avoided in high vibration areas Located to permit inspection Staggered in bundles to minimize increase in bundle size Self-insulated splice connector is preferred
Kept to a minimum and avoided in
high vibration areas
Located to permit inspection
Staggered in bundles to minimize
increase in bundle size
Self-insulated splice connector is
preferred

Terminals
Terminals

Tensile strength of the wire-to- terminal joint should be at least the equivalent tensile strength of the wire The resistance of the wire-to- terminal joint should be negligible relative to the normal resistance or the wire
Tensile strength of the wire-to-
terminal joint should be at least the
equivalent tensile strength of the
wire
The resistance of the wire-to-
terminal joint should be negligible
relative to the normal resistance or
the wire

Terminal Strips
Terminal Strips

Barriers to prevent adjacent studs from contacting each other Current should be carried by terminal contact surface and not by the stud Studs anchored against rotation Mounted such that loose metallic objects cannot fall across terminals
Barriers to prevent adjacent studs
from contacting each other
Current should be carried by
terminal contact surface and not by
the stud
Studs anchored against rotation
Mounted such that loose metallic
objects cannot fall across terminals

Terminal Strips
Terminal Strips

Terminal should be periodically inspected for loose connections, metallic objects, dirt, and grease accumulation. These types of conditions can cause arcing which may result in a fire or systems failure.
Terminal should be periodically
inspected for loose connections,
metallic objects, dirt, and grease
accumulation. These types of
conditions can cause arcing which
may result in a fire or systems
failure.

Terminal Lugs
Terminal Lugs

Used to connect wiring to terminal block studs No more than 4 lugs or three lugs and a bus bar per stud Lug hole size should match the stud diameter
Used to connect wiring to terminal
block studs
No more than 4 lugs or three lugs
and a bus bar per stud
Lug hole size should match the
stud diameter

greatest diameter on bottom, smallest on top 41 Tightening terminal connections should not deform lugs
greatest diameter on bottom,
smallest on top
41
Tightening terminal connections
should not deform lugs

Terminal Lugs
Terminal Lugs

Aluminum Lugs
Aluminum Lugs

crimped to aluminum wire only
crimped to aluminum wire only

Special attention needed to guard against excessive voltage drop at terminal junction
Special attention needed to guard
against excessive voltage drop at
terminal junction

• Inadequate terminal contact area • Stacking errors • improper torquing Use calibrated crimp tools
• Inadequate terminal contact area • I n a d e q u a t e
t e r m i n a l
c o n t a c t
a r e a
• Stacking errors • S t a c k i n g
e r r o r s
• improper torquing • i m p r o p e r
t o r q u i n g
Use calibrated crimp tools

Grounding
Grounding

Types of Grounding
Types of Grounding

AC returns DC returns others
AC returns
DC returns
others

Mixing return currents from various sources should be avoided because noise will be coupled from one source to another and can be a major problem for digital systems
Mixing return currents from various
sources should be avoided
because noise will be coupled from
one source to another and can be
a major problem for digital systems

Grounding
Grounding

Design of ground path should be given as much attention as other leads in the system Should provide a constant impedance Equipment items should be externally grounded even when internally grounded
Design of ground path should be
given as much attention as other
leads in the system
Should provide a constant
impedance
Equipment items should be
externally grounded even when
internally grounded

Grounding
Grounding

Heavy current grounds
Heavy current grounds

Must be attached to individual grounding brackets that are attached to aircraft structure with a proper metal-to-metal bond. Must accommodate normal and fault currents of the system without creating excessive voltage drop or damage to the structure Special attention needed for composite aircraft
Must be attached to individual
grounding brackets that are
attached to aircraft structure with a
proper metal-to-metal bond.
Must accommodate normal and
fault currents of the system without
creating excessive voltage drop or
damage to the structure
Special attention needed for
composite aircraft

Wire Marking
Wire Marking

Necessary to provide safety of operation, safety to maintenance personnel, and ease of maintenance Common practice for wire the manufacturers to use wire material part number and the five digit/letter code identifying the manufacturer to identify performance capability
Necessary to provide safety of
operation, safety to maintenance
personnel, and ease of
maintenance
Common practice for wire the
manufacturers to use wire material
part number and the five digit/letter
code identifying the manufacturer
to identify performance capability

Wire Marking
Wire Marking

Wire identification marks identify the wire, the circuit it belongs to, and its gauge size. All markings should be legible in size, type, and color. 15 inch maximum intervals along the wire (direct or sleeve/tag) >3 inches needs no marking readable without removing clamps, ties, or supporting devices
Wire identification marks identify
the wire, the circuit it belongs to,
and its gauge size. All markings
should be legible in size, type, and
color.
15 inch maximum intervals along
the wire (direct or sleeve/tag)
>3 inches needs no marking
readable without removing clamps,
ties, or supporting devices

Connectors
Connectors

Multitude of types. Crimped contacts are generally used. Some of the more common are Round cannon type Rectangular Module Blocks
Multitude of types. Crimped
contacts are generally used. Some
of the more common are
Round cannon type
Rectangular
Module Blocks

Should be selected to provide the maximum degree of safety and 48 reliability considering electrical and environmental requirements
Should be selected to provide the
maximum degree of safety and
48
reliability considering electrical and
environmental requirements

Connectors
Connectors

Environmental resistant connectors should be used in applications subject to fluids, vibration, thermal, mechanical shock, and/or corrosive elements When HIRF/Lightning protection is required, special attention should be given to the terminations of individual or overall shields
Environmental resistant connectors
should be used in applications
subject to fluids, vibration, thermal,
mechanical shock, and/or
corrosive elements
When HIRF/Lightning protection is
required, special attention should
be given to the terminations of
individual or overall shields

Conduits Primary purpose is for mechanical protection or wires or cables Should have absence of abrasion at end fittings Proper clamping required Adequate drain points free of obstructions Located to minimize damage from moving objects Proper bend radii
Conduits
Primary purpose is for mechanical
protection or wires or cables
Should have absence of abrasion
at end fittings
Proper clamping required
Adequate drain points free of
obstructions
Located to minimize damage from
moving objects
Proper bend radii
